Description: Man of Sorrows, after Martin Schongauer; Christ wearing the Crown of Thorns with hands on chest, supported by the Virgin and St John the Evangelist; in the foreground the image of the sudarium attached to the front of the sarcophagus. c.1495-1500 Engraving
Curator's comments: This engraving belongs to a group of eight unsigned prints which Hind tentatively attributed to Robetta, but now generally accepted as autograph (apart from two that appear to be questionable: see P&D 1845-8-25-801). It is an early work, in which the figures still show a certain stiffness and awkwardness. Other impressions are in Bologna (Pinacoteca Nazionale), Florence (Biblioteca Marucelliana) and in the Rothschild collection (Louvre, Paris). For a discussion of Robetta's oeuvre see Hind D.II.4 (P&D Kk.8.30). The composition is copied (in reverse) from Schongauer's 'Man of Sorrows' (Bartsch 69; Hollstein 34), although Schongauer's Gothic frame and the angels above are omitted. The representation of the sudarium (the cloth miraculously bearing an image of Christ's face) is analogous to that in Robetta's signed 'Resurrection' (Hind D.II.15; M. J. Zucker, 'The Illustrated Bartsch, Commentary', vol. 25, part 2, 1984, p. 545, no. 018). From its dimensions and shape the engraving was possibly engraved on the same plate of the 'Flight into Egypt' (Hind D.II.38; M. J. Zucker, 'The Illustrated Bartsch, Commentary', vol. 25, part 2, 1984, pp. 539-40, no. 013).
